description: The present tutorial page explains how to calculate the surface energy for the simple case of crystalline copper, using Quantum ESPRESSO.
title: Exabyte.io Tutorial: Calculate Surface Energy

youTubeCaptions.text: Create a simulation, by navigating to the job designer page.
Then, <break time='0.5' /> open the materials tab, and choose a surface of Gold oriented along the [1,1,1] axis, as a case study.

We now take a closer look at the gold slab, with the help of the Materials interactive viewer interface. <break time='6.0' /> We can, for instance, zoom into the image, or rotate it, for better visualization.

Then, <break time='0.5' /> open the workflow tab, and choose the 'Surface Energy' workflow by selecting it in the list. <break time='0.5' /> This workflow can be imported from the bank, if it is not already listed.

We take a look at the list of units for performing the surface energy computation, displayed at the bottom. <break time='0.5' /> The logic behind such units is described in detail in the main tutorial text, linked in the video description.

We now navigate to the 'Important Settings' tab, and set the size of the grid of k-points to <sub alias='eight by eight by one'>8x8x1</sub>, since the normal vector to the surface is along the z axis.
After that, <break time='0.5' /> navigate to compute tab, and set compute configuration. <break time='3.0' /> Here, we use one node with eight cores on the OR8 queue.
Then, <break time='0.5' /> set the name for the job. <break time='2.0' /> Here, we call it - Gold Surface Energy Calculation.
Next, <break time='0.5' /> save the job. <break time='5.0' /> It can then be selected and submitted to the compute queue, for execution.
The status of the calculation will change from pre-submitted to submitted, and then to active.
When the job is finished, open it, to inspect the final results.

The final result for the surface energy of our gold surface can be found under the results page. <break time='1.0' /> The surface energy in this case is of around 0.049 <sub alias='electronvolts per Angstrom squared'>eV/A^2</sub>.
